entry.title: Mozilla, eScience
entry.summary:
Last month, I grabbed a beer with Kay Thaney and chatted about various M/S and Data Science and eScience and other activities; it was a great chat. One consequence is that Kay invited Jake VanderPlas and I to present about the Data Science Incubator on the Mozilla Science Lab Call yesterday. We spent 5 or 10 minutes explaining what the what the eScience Institute is, what the Data Science Incubator is, giving some example participants, and taking questions. You can see the call notes at the linked Etherpad.

We began interviews for a web content strategist today. More on that when I’m allowed to talk about it.

Finally, I met with Camille to discuss her work on automatically generating visualizations. This work has been greatly advanced by conversations I had with viz-whiz Aritra Dasgupta at NYU last month, and we now have a concrete idea for how to frame the problem. Here’s the question:

  • Overall problem: a user loads a dataset and then executes a series of automated, semi-automated, or manual steps to specify a visualization.
  • Existing, commonly-used tools for this task include Tableau, IPython Notebook, etc., each of which has its own strengths and weaknesses.

Question: does knowing the query/queries that generated the dataset let you automate more? In particular, given the dataset and queries alone, can we suggest the visualization the user wants to draw? What if we add workload information?

We’re confident the answer to these is “yes”. More to come!

entry.title: Visualizations everywhere
entry.summary:
Kristin Tufte from Portland State University came to UW today to visit some folks in transportation and to visit our eScience and Database groups. Most of the eScience students got to tell her about their work, and she and I discussed the Data Science Incubator and how to get undergrads involved. In her talk, she told us about S-Store, a streaming database with transactional support, and all about her work building Portal to manage, analyze, and visualize live traffic data on the Portland—Vancouver(WA) border in collaboration with ODOT, WSDOT, and related gov’ts. Fascinating, big, messy data problems everywhere, and great output viz.

Dominik Moritz & I chatted about his research on Myria’s profiler / query execution visualizer and the paper we hope to write about it this quarter. I have been logging a half-dozen ways in which the profiler has helped me debug and understand various system this summer and these use cases should help flesh out the paper.

Camille Cobb & I chatted about various projects for her relating to visualization of scientific datasets. We’re doing lit review and reading up on existing work, but I think we have the gist of two interesting, novel projects to go on.

In my own time, I have been struggling with using SQLAlchemy on Google App Engine to make Myria push work into an underlying DBMS and get much better performance on selective queries.
